title: About Me
text: Hi! I‚Äôm Jordan Patten Hardy: student researcher, social impact‚Äìdriven engineer, and avid design enthusiast. I‚Äôm a Junior Mechanical Engineering student at Brigham Young University, and I believe in engineering for the good of the world.

title: Jordan Patten Hardy
text: />

title: The Mechanics of Mixing: Designing a Next-Generation Hand Mixer
text:
This project aimed to modernize an existing design by enhancing its appearance and implementing mechanical improvements for better functionality.



Comparison between Current Generation Smeg Hand Mixer and Next Generation Design




The benchmark design for this next generation model is the SMEG Hand Mixer HMF01. After examining the reviews placed by consumers, it was clear that many features were well-loved, but others still had room for improvement. Based on these reviews and personal experience, some changes that I decided to make for the Next-Generation of the SMEG Hand Mixer include:

An eject button for taking the beaters out instead of an eject switch, allowing for easier access and a smoother eject process.
An included charger case so the cord doesn‚Äôt get in the way during use, transitioning the mixer to be powered by a rechargeable battery.
An included bowl rest located near the bottom back of the mixer so that a user can set the mixer on the edge of the bowl when not in use.
A larger surface area on the ergonomic grip (a highly rated feature).
An included storage case (combined with charger case) so the user can easily keep track of attachments.
A styling update, including a flatter handle that doesn‚Äôt connect back into the body at the back.
Modernization, including an updated button / screen interface.







Parts of Completed Assembly







Key Features of Next-Gen Design





The next generation design also keeps recognizable and consumer approved features of the original design, namely:

The same approximate size
The smooth, retro look
The self-balancing design
The nine speed options and LED display with set timer











Ideation Sketches




After deciding what changes to make for the next generation design, I began sketching ideas to implement each design change. Once I had chosen a design, I moved into the 3D modeling phase.







I began by sketching the steps for each part of the mixer. Then, using the parametric modeling platform Onshape, I created my model.

Most parts in the assembly were created using a master model and offset surfaces.
The body of the master model was created with a revolve.
The handle was formed using a complex loft that follows a guide curve.






Final Design

















Thickness AnalysisInjection Molding Prep







Interference Check Mechanical Clearances







Zebra AnalysisCurvature Continuity





During the iterative modeling process, I conducted a series of computational validations to ensure manufacturing readiness:

Interference Testing: Verified that all internal gear meshes and housing tolerances were intentional, preventing mechanical clashing.
Thickness Analysis: Confirmed constant wall thickness across the chassis to facilitate high-quality injection molding.
Zebra Striping: Evaluated surface continuity to ensure light reflections flow smoothly across the curves of the mixer.










Engineering Drawings




The final step after hours of parametric modeling was to document my work. This includes the creation of engineering drawings and the complilation of a design package.



View the complete documentation here

title: The Marmot‚Äôs Margin of Error: Quantifying the Groundhog‚Äôs Gaze
text:
The aim of this project was to evaluate the accuracy of Punxsutawney Phil‚Äôs Groundhog Day predictions using historical weather data. Specifically, it investigates whether Phil‚Äôs shadow-based forecasts correlate with actual changes in average temperatures between February and March.




Photo by Camerauthor Photos on Unsplash

title: The Modulus of Merriment: Selection Science for the Simply Supported Swing
text:
For this project, I needed to select a material for a swingset crossbeam. I modeled a swing set crossbeam as a simply supported beam under a center load to identify the materials that met a maximum deflection limit of 0.5 mm. I compared several materials for stiffness, weight, cost, and durability, then created a graph and table in Excel to visualize performance and determine the optimal material under given the design constraints.



Photo by Dan Meyers on Unsplash

title: The Power of Pneumatics: A Study in Reciprocating Motion
text:
This project aimed to modernize an existing design by enhancing its appearance and implementing mechanical improvements for better functionality.



Completed Pneumatic Engine

title: The Power of Pneumatics: A Study in Reciprocating Motion
text:
title
As part of a four-person team tasked with improving an engine design, I proposed and implemented modifications to enhance the manufacturability of a pneumatic engine assembly. We developed detailed process sheets for each component, specifying appropriate tooling and machining operations, and manufactured components using a range of techniques including CNC milling, manual turning, sand casting, and powder metallurgy.



Video
Runtime Video



Once all components were manufactured, the engine was fully assembled and tested. As a result of the team‚Äôs design modifications, the engine operated at a lower PSI than any other team‚Äôs engine built from the same initial design and specifications. A comprehensive design report was compiled, including detailed engineering drawings, process sheets for each part, documentation of implemented design changes, and recommendations for future improvements.
View the complete prototyping package here
View the complete design report here

title: The Marmot‚Äôs Margin of Error: Quantifying the Groundhog‚Äôs Gaze
text:
The aim of this project was to evaluate the accuracy of Punxsutawney Phil‚Äôs Groundhog Day predictions using historical weather data. Specifically, it investigates whether Phil‚Äôs shadow-based forecasts correlate with actual changes in average temperatures between February and March.




Photo by Camerauthor Photos on Unsplash

title: The Marmot‚Äôs Margin of Error: Quantifying the Groundhog‚Äôs Gaze
text:
Intro
Every year on February 2nd, thousands gather in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania, awaiting the spring forecast from the world‚Äôs most famous groundhog, Punxsutawney Phil. According to tradition, if Phil sees his shadow, six more weeks of winter are expected. However, if he doesn‚Äôt see his shadow, an early spring is on the way.
While the event is a beloved cultural ritual, many question the accuracy of Phil‚Äôs predictions. Is there any truth behind the shadow-based forecasting, or is it simply superstition? To investigate, I analyzed historical average temperature data alongside Phil‚Äôs annual predictions to evaluate whether his forecasts align with actual weather patterns. Leaning toward belief rather than skepticism, I hypothesized that Punxsutawney Phil is correct more than half of the time.

title: The Marmot‚Äôs Margin of Error: Quantifying the Groundhog‚Äôs Gaze
text:
Methods
To test this hypothesis, a one-sample hypothesis test for proportions was used. The null hypothesis was that Phil is correct less than or equal to 50% of the time. The alternative hypothesis was that he is correct more than 50% of the time. I set conditions for a ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù prediction and analyzed the data under four different thresholds for defining winter (a difference of 0¬∞C (no change), the mean of the distribution (7.88‚Ñâ increase), the median (7.96‚Ñâ increase), the 25th percentile (5.29‚Ñâ increase) ). Using if statements in Python, I determined whether each prediction was correct according to the defined threshold, and calculated the proportion of correct predictions for each method. For hypothesis testing and confidence intervals, I used norm.cdf or norm.ppf from the scipy.stats library.

title: The Marmot‚Äôs Margin of Error: Quantifying the Groundhog‚Äôs Gaze
text:
Results
Results for the evaluation of the proportion of correct predictions for each definition of winter are shown in Figure 1.

After calculating the proportion of correct predictions, I used a one-sample hypothesis test for proportions, with hypotheses outlined in the methods section. The results are outlined in Table 1, along with the results for a 95% confidence interval for the true population proportion of accurate predictions. None of the p values for the proportion of predictions were statistically significant at a level of ùõÇ = 0.05.



Table¬†1: A summary of statistics obtained from a hypothesis test for proportions and a computed confidence interval for a population proportion of correct predictions made by Punxsutawney Phil.











Method
95% Confidence Interval
P Value
Statistically Significant (\(ùõÇ = 0.05\))




Mean/Median
\([0.425, 0.575]\)
\(0.5\)
No


25th Percentile
\([0.263, 0.404]\)
\(0.999\)
No


Difference of Zero
\([0.096, 0.204]\)
\(1.0\)
No

title: The Marmot‚Äôs Margin of Error: Quantifying the Groundhog‚Äôs Gaze
text:
Discussion
Because none of the p values are large, we have no basis for rejecting our null hypothesis. Therefore, we fail to reject the null hypothesis, and cannot conclude that Phil‚Äôs predictions are correct more than 50 percent of the time. It appears that Punxsutawney Phil‚Äôs predictions do not significantly outperform random chance under any of the thresholds tested. While the folklore is entertaining and charming, the data suggests that Phil may not be a reliable source of meteorological insight. Similarly, the calculated confidence intervals provide a region in which we can be 95% confident that the true population proportion of correct predictions lies.
View the complete report here

title: The Marmot‚Äôs Margin of Error: Quantifying the Groundhog‚Äôs Gaze
text:
Introduction
Every year on February 2nd, thousands gather in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania, awaiting the spring forecast from the world‚Äôs most famous groundhog, Punxsutawney Phil. According to tradition, if Phil sees his shadow, six more weeks of winter are expected. However, if he doesn‚Äôt see his shadow, an early spring is on the way.
While the event is a beloved cultural ritual, many question the accuracy of Phil‚Äôs predictions. Is there any truth behind the shadow-based forecasting, or is it simply superstition? To investigate, I analyzed historical average temperature data alongside Phil‚Äôs annual predictions to evaluate whether his forecasts align with actual weather patterns. Leaning toward belief rather than skepticism, I hypothesized that Punxsutawney Phil is correct more than half of the time.

title: The Modulus of Merriment: Selection Science for the Simply Supported Swing
text:
For this project, I needed to select a material for a swingset crossbeam. I modeled a swing set crossbeam as a simply supported beam under a center load to identify the materials that met a maximum deflection limit of 0.5 mm. I compared several materials for stiffness, weight, cost, and durability, then created a graph and table in Excel to visualize performance and determine the optimal material under given the design constraints.

title: The Logic of Light: Creating Collision-Free Pathfinding Systems
text:
The aim of this project was to build a robot capable of following a light source in a dark environment with integrated collision protection and servo control.



Video
Runtime Video

title: The Logic of Light: Creating Collision-Free Pathfinding Systems
text:
The aim of this project was to build a robot capable of following a light source in a dark environment with integrated collision protection and servo control.



Video
Runtime Video

title: The Logic of Light: Creating Collision-Free Pathfinding Systems
text:
Key aspects included:
Circuit Design: Assembled and tested circuits using resistors, capacitors, voltage sources (battery), DC motors, and a breadboard.
Embedded Systems & Control Logic: Programmed an Arduino and used a finite state machine to control the robot‚Äôs behavior.
Mechanical Problem Solving: Diagnosed and resolved wheel slippage by adding rubber bands for traction, improving mobility and performance.

title: The Logic of Light: Creating Collision-Free Pathfinding Systems
text:
Key aspects of the project

Circuit Design: Assembled and tested circuits using resistors, capacitors, voltage sources (battery), DC motors, and a breadboard.
Embedded Systems & Control Logic: Programmed an Arduino and used a finite state machine to control the robot‚Äôs behavior.
Mechanical Problem Solving: Diagnosed and resolved wheel slippage by adding rubber bands for traction, improving mobility and performance.

title: The Geometry of Gameplay: A Parametric Tribute to the NES Controller
text:
The goal of this project was to recreate Nintendo‚Äôs iconic NES controller as a fully parametric CAD model. It prioritized dimensional accuracy and adaptability for future design changes.



Completed Assembly

title: The Geometry of Gameplay: A Parametric Tribute to the NES Controller
text:
The goal of this project was to recreate Nintendo‚Äôs iconic NES controller as a fully parametric CAD model. It prioritized dimensional accuracy and adaptability for future design changes.



Completed Assembly

title: The Geometry of Gameplay: A Parametric Tribute to the NES Controller
text:
The controller was modeled using engineering drawings drawn by C.¬†A.&nbsp ~Mattson.
CAD operations used in the completion of this project include lofts, revolves, sweeps, and patterns.
Many parts were modeled, including the Start/Select Buttons, the A/B Buttons, the D-Pad, the Top and Bottom covers (with supports and rib bosses) and the PCB. Other parts, such as the charging cord, were provided as part of the project.




Exploded View Assemly

title: The Geometry of Gameplay: A Parametric Tribute to the NES Controller
text:
Project Details

The controller was modeled using engineering drawings drawn by C.¬†A.¬†Mattson.
CAD operations used in the completion of this project include lofts, revolves, sweeps, and patterns.
I modeled many of the parts, including the Start/Select Buttons, the A/B Buttons, the D-Pad, the Top and Bottom covers (with supports and rib bosses) and the PCB. Other parts, such as the charging cord, were provided as part of the project.




Exploded View Assemly

title: The Bricks of Bangkok: Reconstructing a Robotic Icon
text: This project focused on designing and constructing an original architectural model using LEGO elements. It involved developing a configuration generator to explore design variations, followed by extensive assembly to bring the final concept to life. All work was done on the Onshape CAD platform.

title: The Bricks of Bangkok: Reconstructing a Robotic Icon
text:
The Robot Building-CAD Modeling
I chose to design a hypothetical LEGO architecture set inspired by the Bank of Asia in Bangkok, Thailand‚Äîaffectionately known as The Robot Building. The structure appealed to me because of its unique shape and fun appearance.



Illustration of the stages of the LEGO structure design


After developing an assembly plan (included in the complete documentation), I opened an Assembly Studio in Onshape and began construction. Using the configuration generator, I inserted the required pieces and sourced any special, non-rectangular elements from a provided database. I especially enjoyed this project as it allowed me to merge structured engineering design with creativity‚Äîbringing my inner child to life
View the complete documentation here
